author: Barton Swaim
title: Politics: Pen Portraits and Table Talk
text:
By my reckoning, when Associate Justice Antonin Scalia died two years ago, he was the most famous member of the Supreme Court. His fame, remarkably, has only increased since then. With the exceptions of justices famous for historical reasons—Thurgood Marshall, Sandra Day O’Connor—judges are ordinarily forgotten by everybody but law-school students. Exceptions are rare: Louis Brandeis, Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. It’s too early to know if Scalia is one of those exceptions, but it feels that way.
His name was at the center of...
